channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Media Feed Bias Against Latinos
item.description: A newly released survey of Americans' attitudes toward Hispanics says prejudice against the country's fastest-growing minority is perpetuated by negative media portrayals.
item.dc:creator: By LUISITA LOPEZ TORREGROSA

item.title: Ex-Police Chief in China Scandal Aided Prosecutors
item.description: The chief, Wang Lijun, who is connected to the downfall of Bo Xilai, confessed to the most serious charge against him, but his cooperation in the case suggested he would be spared the death sentence.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The former chief Wang Lijun confessed in court, but officials added that he helped prosecutors.

item.title: China Warns Japan Over Island Dispute
item.description: China drove home its opposition to Japanese control of a contested group of islands Tuesday, with angry protests in dozens of cities and a warning from its defense minister that “further actions” were possible.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON and THOM SHANKER
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters threw water bottles at the well-guarded Japanese Embassy in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: French Court Rebukes Magazine for Photos of Royal Couple
item.description: The court ordered the publisher of the magazine Closer to hand over all digital copies of images of the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, sunbathing topless in France.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: 11 European Foreign Ministers Call for Greater Integration
item.description: The foreign ministers, led by Germany’s Guido Westerwelle, have called for a big increase in economic, political, diplomatic and even military integration within the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Myanmar’s Opposition Leader Urges End to Sanctions
item.description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi began a trip to the United States that is a sign of the great shift in relations in the past year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi met with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton at the State Department on Tuesday.

item.title: Arctic Resources, Exposed by Warming, Set Off Competition
item.description: The jockeying among nations has begun as areas of the Arctic once regarded as barren wastelands now offer an abundance of oil, gas and minerals.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

item.title: Pakistani Government Relents in Judicial Standoff Over Corruption Case
item.description: Pakistan’s government on Tuesday agreed to write a letter to the authorities in Switzerland regarding corruption charges against President Asif Ali Zardari.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Historian Says Piece of Papyrus Refers to Jesus’ Wife
item.description: A Harvard historian of early Christianity said the papyrus, written in Coptic in the fourth century, contains a phrase never seen in any piece of Scripture: “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife ...’ ”
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Evan McGlinn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professor Karen L. King, in her office at Harvard Divinity School, held a fragment of papyrus that she says was written in Coptic in the fourth century and contains a reference to Jesus' wife.

item.title: Turks Weary of Leaders’ Support for Syria Uprising
item.description: Although many Turks at first agreed with their government’s support for the Syrian opposition, many now believe it is undermining Turkey’s economy and security.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Syrian refugees at the Altinozu camp in Turkey, near the border with Syria.

item.title: Russia Demands U.S. End Support of Democracy Groups
item.description: The Kremlin views American financial support for a wide range of civil society programs as thinly veiled meddling in the country’s internal affairs.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Afghan Suicide Bomber Strikes Minibus Carrying Foreigners
item.description: A suicide bomber killed 14 people on Tuesday including 10 foreigners, most of whom worked as flight crew members under contract with the United States government.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SANGAR RAHIMI
item.media:description: Men assisted two distraught brothers of a minibus driver killed in Kabul on Tuesday.

item.title: Coalition Sharply Reduces Joint Operations With Afghan Troops
item.description: A spike in attacks on international troops by Afghan soldiers and police pushed the American-led military coalition to curb ground operations with their Afghan counterparts.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan soldier, left, on patrol with an American soldier in the Barakzai hamlet of Sangsar. Similar operations in the future will require approval by a general.

item.title: Keystrokes in Google Bare Shocking Rumors About Bettina Wulff
item.description: A former first lady of Germany is suing the search engine over Google’s autocomplete function and rumors that she was once an escort.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Former first lady of Germany, Bettina Wulff, and her husband, Christian Wulff, who resigned as president in February.

item.title: Ally of India’s Governing Coalition Withdraws Her Support
item.description: Mamata Banerjee, the mercurial chief minister of West Bengal and a crucial ally of India’s governing coalition, angrily announced that she was withdrawing her support for the coalition.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: First Uterus Transplants From Mother to Daughter Are Reported
item.description: Doctors in Sweden have performed the world’s first mother-to-daughter uterus transplants, a medical team said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Female Officers Die in Ambush
item.description: One of Britain’s most wanted fugitives killed two unarmed police officers, both women, on Tuesday, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Prince Charles Loses Ruling on Letters
item.description: A tribunal in London ruled that letters written by Prince Charles lobbying government ministers on a range of contentious political issues must be made public within a month.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: 8 Charged Over Anti-Islam Film
item.description: Egypt’s general prosecutor issued arrest warrants on Tuesday for seven Egyptian Coptic Christians and an American pastor in connection with an anti-Islam film that has set off riots across the Muslim world.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Rebels Are Reportedly Fleeing
item.description: Fighters from Somalia’s Islamist extremist rebels have started to leave their remaining coastal stronghold, Kismayo, in the face of advancing allied African troops, residents and a military official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Changing Greenland
item.description: The warming climate has expanded the possibility of oil and mineral exploitation in the Arctic, bringing a construction boom to Nuuk, the capital of Greenland.

item.title: 11 European Foreign Ministers Call for Greater Integration
item.description: The foreign ministers, led by Germany’s Guido Westerwelle, have called for a big increase in economic, political, diplomatic and even military integration within the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Thai Truth Commission Warns of Simmering Conflicts
item.description: A panel investigating deadly protests in 2010 that left more than 90 dead blamed the powerful Thai military and a shadowy group of militants, the black shirts.
item.dc:creator: By POYPITI AMATATHAM and THOMAS FULLER

item.title: The Lede Blog: Mitt Romney's No-State Solution
item.description: Mitt Romney said privately in May that "there's just no way" for an independent Palestinian state to be established on the West Bank territory Israel has occupied since 1967.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Possible Breakthrough in Math’s ABC Conjecture
item.description: A Japanese mathematician has released 500 pages of work on a problem known as the abc conjecture. Other mathematicians are excited, but bewildered by the proof.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
